transcripts.text: Fuck, this is impossible!  If only there could be some kind of platform where people with no talent can say things and get taken seriously.  What?  Count Dankula responded to my video.  Amazing.  I guess I need to make a response to his response now.  He seems kind of annoyed that I started the video by talking about the BNP.

What are you talking about, Dankula?  I know that this whole video is about your right-wing comedy, but me putting a bunch of stuff from the BNP at the start is unrelated.  It has nothing to do with Dankula's comedy.  Wink, wink.  You know, and I said it was unrelated, so what are you talking about, man?  If you're going to lie, at least be good at it.  This is just Lonerbox lying again.  Liarbox, there we go.

So I do have a pretty simple explanation for this.  It was a joke.  But in case I offended anyone, I should clarify that I don't think Dankula is a white supremacist or that he has anything to do with the BNP.  Nor did I ever say he did.  Apparently I ignored the much more central point that the black man was being racist towards white people and... I had thought about doing the whole response where I watch his video and then pause and say, that's wrong.  and here's why.  But for the sake of my audience, I'm just going to put it in a pinned comment below so I can talk about something more interesting.  And if you think that makes me a soft boy, beta Marxist soy brain, you're wrong.  I was already all of those things.  Instead, I thought I'd talk about something that's a bit closer to home, freedom of speech.  Because Marcus isn't just a comedian.  He's also an activist who opposes British hate speech laws on the grounds that they allow the government to infringe on people's human rights.  Here he is in a recent video where he offers his seasoned activist perspective on the matter.

A huge free speech movement has started developing in the UK and has been growing for the last four years.  A lot of the younger generation are just loving freedom and loving freedom of speech.  People like to be able to speak their mind, especially against the powers that be, which is why the powers that be exist.  hate freedom of speech?  oh no it's to fight.  it's to fight racism and bigotry.  yeah yeah that's that's what china and north korea said at first as well.  it's to fight racism and bigotry.  yeah yeah that's that's what china and north korea said at first as well and fucking look at them now.  right we know you're in game right?  not fucking stupid.
So, Dankula's position is that anti-free speech legislation in the UK is mostly a product of the left.
But the problem is that the laws that we have right now controlling freedom of speech in the UK have all come from the left.  The law that I was charged under was passed by the Labour Party.

So here he points out that the law he was sentenced under, Section 127 of the Communications Act, which deemed it a crime to commit gross offence, was passed in 2003 by the Labour Party.  I could get bogged down here and question exactly how left-wing he thinks Tony Blair's government was, but maybe I don't need to.  Because what he probably won't tell you is that the Communications Act was mostly made up of laws that already existed, but had to be repurposed for the internet and to consolidate regulatory powers under a new organization called Ofcom.  These laws came under the Telecommunications Act, section 43 of which contained this very familiar passage, which deemed it criminal for someone to send a message or other matter.  that is grossly offensive.  Quite poetically, because I know how much Dankula likes his Orwell references, The Telecommunications Act was passed in 1984 under a conservative government.  Of course, this was a long time ago, but as for the conservatives today, Dangula had this to say about them.

Labour actively want to pass, the two primary parties in Britain is Labour and the Conservatives, right?  Labour actively want to pass laws to restrict freedom of speech.  But that doesn't mean that I like the Tories.  Now, the Tories aren't doing anything against freedom of speech, but they're also not doing anything for it because the Tories just simply don't give a shit.

So the distinction he's making here is quite clear.  The far left are the ones trying to censor free speech.  And whilst the Tories aren't doing anything to help, they're also not doing anything to make matters worse.  However, since the return to power in 2010, the Conservative Party have also introduced laws such as the Snoopers Charter, which requires internet providers and phone companies to hold people's data for at least 12 months.  In 2014, they briefly banned British porn producers from depicting what they deemed content that is not acceptable.  Their list of categories which met this definition included face-sitting and female ejaculation.  And they say we don't need feminism anymore.  And in 2015, they radically expanded on Tony Blair's prevent strategy by making it the duty of schools and universities to denounce people who were showing signs of extremism.  The policy has been frequently criticized for having little success in catching extremists despite being fairly aggressive.  People as young as 13 have found themselves detained and questioned.
